ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

GOVERNMENT ACCOMMODATION FOR REVENUE OFFICERS
AND MARINE STAFF


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance what is the position with reference to Government accommodation available for Revenue Officers and Marine Staff of the Customs and Excise Department.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the Customs and Excise Department there are at present 376 Revenue officers of all grades and 115 Marine Staff. Under their terms of service, the Revenue Officers may be required to reside in institutional quarters, and 207 of them are occupying Government quarters. Although the terms of service of the Marine Staff do not require them to stay in institutional quarters, 58 of them are, however, occupying quarters. The remaining 56 quarters Out of a total of 321 under the control of the Customs and Excise Department are occupied by other grades.

    Mr David Marshall: Would the Minister indicate whether any assistance would be given by Government, or any contemplated provision by Government, for increasing the accommodation for both the Revenue Officers and the Marine Staff?

Column: 224



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Expansion of quarters is being provided for in the State Development Plan. This year another 24 Division III quarters would be built for the accommodation of Revenue Officers, and another 32 quarters next year.

REPORTS ON STEEL MILLS AND ON INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether it is the Government's intention to table (a) the Schereschewsky Report on Steel Mills and (b) the Winsemius Report on Industrial Development, and when will they be tabled.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not the intention of the Government to publish these two Reports. Both Reports were made to the Government on a confidential basis and cannot be published without the consent of the U.N, agencies to which the experts belong.

    The Schereschewsky Mission made recommendations on the establishment of a steel industry in Singapore which could be carried out in three phases. The first phase is to start immediately. The second phase is to be implemented when conditions are favourable and after certain technical studies have been completed.

    No time has been lost in carrying out the recommendations of the steel mission in respect of the first phase. The steel plant is in the course of establishment at Jurong.

    The Winsemius Mission made recommendations on the establishment of certain specific industries in various fields. In addition, they made recommendations on general economic policy as well as a review on present potential strength and sources and weaknesses.

    The expert missions sent by the United Nations are of value only if they are able to make recommendations to the best of their judgement and ability. They must not be inhibited by any possibility that their analysis of the problem and recommendations as to solutions would be the subject of public political

Column: 225

controversy. For this reason the Government cannot publish the Reports of the two expert missions.

    The technical details of the Winsemius Report, such as the type of industries that could be established, the scale of plant, manufacturing processes suitable to Singapore, and other technical details are being made available to investors who are contemplating setting up a factory in Singapore. This work is carried out by the Economic Development Board.

    Mr David Marshall: The Minister seems to have given two reasons. I do not know whether they are exclusive or supplementary. Do I understand that the Report is not confidential to the Singapore Government but confidential to the United Nations agency which made it? Or do I understand that, in fact, the reason is that it is a policy of the Singapore Government not to make public reports by United Nations agencies? If it is the second, is the Minister aware that there has been publication of United Nations agencies' reports on other topics?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Basically it is a decision of the Singapore Government not to publish this Report. If we decided to publish them or if we wanted to publish them, we would have to obtain the agreement of the United Nations. They may or may not have any objections, but we have never reached that stage because no such application has been made.

    Reports of United Nations missions that have been published are generally studies made by experts in broad fields where either no issues arise which could lead to public or political controversy, or else do not contain information or data or policy guidance which would be in the interests of the Government concerned to keep confidential at least for the time being.

    Mr David Marshall: Does the Minister not consider that it would be helpful to inform interested industrialists of the contents of this Report by making it available so that they should know the data and the position as indicated by an impartial world body?

Column: 226



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said in my reply, technical data on industries and economic appraisals on potential development are being made available to industries. But broad recommendations on policies or strategies that the Government should follow - that part of it we should keep confidential.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has made reference to the steel plant that will soon be coming up. Can the Minister please inform this House of the extent of aid which the Government has granted to this steel plant, in terms of percentage of capital?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: We are assisting the plant in two ways. First, by speeding up work at the Jurong sindustrial site. It is a pity the Member for Cairnhill was not in the party that visited the site last Sunday, but the Member for Anson was, and he could testify that work is being vigorously carried out to level the site and make it ready for occupation. The second way is by share participation. This is not done by the Government directly but by the Economic Development Board and, subject, of course, to correction, my recollection is that the Economic Development Board is participating to the extent of 20 per cent of the total paid-up capital.

LEGISLATION TO COUNTERBALANCE DISPOSAL
OF ESTATES BY WILL


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether Government will consider introducing legislation in this Session (a) to counterbalance, for the protection of dependants, the complete freedom of disposal of estates by Will; and (b) to meet the position whereby part of an intestate's estates is taken by the State where the deceased leaves only a widow and no next-of-kin.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, Bills to curtail the complete freedom of disposal of estates by Will by making statutory provision for the protection of the families and dependants of deceased

Column: 227

status, and to make changes in the law regulating intestates' succession and the right of the State to bona vacantia where the deceased leaves only a widow with no next-of-kin, have been drafted and have been sent to the Singapore Bar Committee for their comments. These Bills will be introduced in the Legislative Assembly after the views of the Singapore Bar Committee have been obtained. But I cannot assure the House that these Bills will be introduced during this Session.

LEGAL AID AND ADVICE ORDINANCE, 1956
(Legal Assistance in criminal matters)


    4. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether Government has any plans for implementation of the provisions of the Legal Aid and Advice Ordinance, 1956, for legal assistance in criminal matters.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is no. It is not considered that the time is opportune for the implementation of the provisions of the Legal Aid and Advice Ordinance, 1956, for legal assistance in criminal matters. The need at the moment is for the raising of the standard of prosecution in criminal cases. No request has been received from the Singapore Bar Committee for the implementation of the provisions of the Ordinance for legal assistance in criminal cases.

    Mr David Marshall: Does the Minister really consider it necessary that the Bar Committee, the economics of whose individual members would be affected by the implementation, would seek implementation of those provisions? Is he going to wait till the Bar Committee asks for the implementation of the provisions of Part II which were passed six years ago?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is not really a case of our waiting for a request from the Singapore Bar Committee. I know that a prosperous lawyer with a lucrative practice like the Member for Anson is not interested in the

Column: 228

workings of the Legal Aid Bureau. But there are other counsel who are prepared to accept briefs from the Legal Aid Bureau. So I think it is unfair to insinuate that the reason why the Bar Committee has made no request for the implementation of the extension of the Ordinance to criminal cases is that it has vested interest in not making this application.

    Mr David Marshall: I am asking the Minister: will he indicate the reason why provisions which were passed six years ago are not considered appropriate for implementation today?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was prepared for this question.

    Under the provisions of the Ordinance regarding legal aid assistance in criminal cases which are not in force, a Judge is obliged to grant free legal aid if he is satisfied that the applicant is without adequate means and that it is in the interests of justice that he should be assisted. It is also provided that any doubts with regard to these matters must be resolved in favour of the applicant. The system also provides for legal assistance in bringing appeals against convictions, and in resisting appeals brought by the Public Prosecutor.

    Excluding the State Advocate-General and the Solicitor-General, there are 10 Crown Counsel fully employed in the State Advocate-General's Chambers in criminal work, and 5 legal officers in the Legal Aid Department to deal with purely civil matters. If the State were to provide for what amounts to free legal aid in nearly all criminal cases by virtue of that presumption which I have referred to, Mr Speaker, Sir, the size of the Legal Aid Department would have to be expanded considerably, and the State would he obliged, in effect, to undertake the defence of all those whom it prosecutes. A substantial amount of the work in the Lower Criminal Courts is concerned with private prosecutions for offences against the Penal Code and the Minor Offences Ordinance for which no assistance is provided by the State. If legal aid were to be extended to criminal cases, these cases could also be brought and defended at public

Column: 229

expense. At present free legal assistance is granted to all persons accused of capital offences. The duty of Government should be to improve the standard of prosecution before introducing legal aid in criminal cases. There is provision in the Estimates for the recruitment of an experienced officer to undertake the prosecution of more important criminal cases so that we can have a prosecutor to match the Member for Anson. But up to date we have not been able to get a suitable person to fill this appointment.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am indebted for your indulgence. I would like to ask the Minister whether he would not consider, in the light of the number of graduates now being turned out by the Faculty of Law of the University of Singapore, whether this is in fact an appropriate time to consider the implementation of provisions which would, it is true, require the enlargement of both the State Advocate-General's Chambers and the free Legal Aid Department.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, this will take time. These graduates are very junior. They have to be trained in the work. I think when the time is opportune - it may not be within this Session - we will be able to do something in that direction.

RESIGNATION OF STAFF NURSES


    5. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law what is the number of staff nurses who have left Government Service since 1st June, 1959, and the general reason therefor.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the total number of staff and student nurses who have left the service since 1st June, 1959, is 228. They resigned for the following reasons:-

    26 resigned on marriage;

    52 left to go to the United Kingdom;

    49 returned to their families in the Federation;

    29 went on oversea study courses and resigned when they were either in England or Australia;

Column: 230



    22 resigned for personal reasons;

    10 to improve their prospects;

    1 died;

    7 were medically boarded out of the service;

    10 went abroad to Borneo, Jesselton and Japan to settle down there, and

    22 gave no reasons for leaving the service.

    In the same period, 617 student nurses and staff nurses were recruited. The approved number of posts for staff nurses and student nurses as at February, 1962, is 1,319. The actual strength is 1,060, leaving 259 vacancies still to be filled.

    Mr David Marshall: I would ask the Minister whether the number given of 228 is abnormal, and if so, whether the rate of remuneration is more favourable in the Federation, thereby attracting our nurses to the Federation service.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is true that the rate of remuneration was better in the Federation until recently when the variable allowance was restored. The position has reversed since. The terms of employment are better now in Singapore than they are in the Federation. Those who left the service to go back to the Federation did so for family reasons. They wished to join their families there.

GOVERNMENT MEDICAL PRACTITIONERS
(Retention of remuneration from private consultations and operations)


    6. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether he would make a statement as to the retention of remuneration by Medical Practitioners in Government Service in respect of private consultations and operations.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, Government medical officers and specialists do not retain consultation fees or operation fees. Consultation fees and operation fees earned by Government medical

Column: 231

officers are paid to revenue. A consultation fee is $25, but is $35 if a consultant has to make a home visit. Operation fees ranged from $25 to $500, and the fee payable depends on the nature of the operation and the accommodation provided to the patient.

    In lieu of the fees previously earned by Government medical officers, Government specialists are paid specialist allowances. These specialist allowances vary from $200 to $500 according to the grade of specialist post the officer holds and whether the appointment is a clinical or an administrative one.

    Certain miscellaneous fees earned by Government medical officers, such as attendance at court, preparation of medical reports and medical certification of workmen's compensation claims, may be retained by Government medical officers up to a maximum of $250 a month. Anything above this is paid to Government revenue. The fees charged for attendance at court are based on a schedule of charges approved by the Registrar of the Supreme Court. These fees are applied to the High Court but are used as a guide by Heads of Departments for determining fees for the lower courts.

    Mr David Marshall: I would inquire whether the Minister would consider giving these specialists the incentive of retaining or receiving part of the fee, because most of the consultations are done outside their normal time in addition to their very heavy work. Does the Minister not consider that an incentive would be helpful in respect of private work from which Government benefit financially?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, there was a lot of abuse with regard to these consultation and operation fees prior to 1958, and as a result a Committee was appointed to look into the whole question. A new procedure has been evolved whereby clinical specialists get a higher allowance in lieu of fees, and non-clinical specialists get a lower allowance, and yet a lower allowance for administrative medical officers. This system has been operating well, and in view of our

Column: 232

past experience, it would be most in-advisable to reintroduce conditions which led to such abuse before.

    Mr David Marshall: Do I understand the Minister then to indicate that, in fact, the specialists are satisfied with these new terms and, if not, would he be prepared to consider representations?

    Mr Byrne: Up to date I have inquired into the position and I am not aware of any dissatisfaction with these specialist allowances. As far as specialists employed by the University are concerned, they have the option of either receiving consultation fees, as Government medical officers did before, or, if not, negotiating separately with the University for a higher pay. The provisions of the Government circular with regard to specialist allowances do not apply to specialist medical officers employed on teaching work in the University.

COMPLAINTS OF POLICE
BRUTALITY


    7. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what is the number of persons who, to the knowledge of the police, have complained of police brutality since 1st June, 1959; and (b) whether he would consider making arrangements that, in cases of such complaints, the complainants should be given an early opportunity to identify the alleged assailants and to make a note of their names and ranks.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there have been 268 cases of complaints of assault by police officers since 1st June, 1959. Of this number, the vast majority, that is, a total of 205 cases, were completely unsubstantiated. They include cases where complaints were investigated and found to be completely false and malicious, and cases which were subsequently withdrawn by the complainants. Of the other 63 cases, 34 cases resulted in appropriate disciplinary action taken against the officers concerned. In seven of the cases, the officers found guilty were dismissed or discharged from the Force. Nine cases resulted in court summonses issued against the officers concerned. In three

Column: 233

cases the summonses were subsequently withdrawn, and in three cases the officers charged were acquitted by the court. The balance of 20 cases are still under investigation.

    With regard to the second part of the question, it has been the practice for the police to afford complainants every opportunity of identifying their alleged assailants in all cases where the cornplainants have stated that they either could or might be able to identify them. Where any police officer has been so identified, there is no objection to his name and rank being supplied to the complainants concerned for the purpose of instituting court action where required.

    Mr David Marshall: Do I understand the Minister to give us an assurance that, in fact, at every such identification parade the name of the officer identified will be given to the complainant?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Yes, it will be supplied.

    Mr David Marshall: Would the Minister consider whether it is appropriate for complaints against police officers to be investigated by some separate body rather than by the police themselves?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is a question which I have been toying for the last two and a half years. In view of the fact that the police is a disciplined force, professional advice is that it is most unwise to do so.

SATURDAY POST
(Application for circulation in Singapore)


    8. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he has received an application from the Saturday Post, a Malayan weekly, for circulation in Singapore, and what action he has taken or proposes to take thereon.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, an application was received on 24th January, 1962, from Mr James S. David of Kuala Lumpur for a permit for the

Column: 234

distribution in Singapore of the Saturday Post. Mr David has been informed that the application could not be approved.

    Mr David Marshall: Would the Minister care to enlighten us on the reasons for the refusal of a permit to circulate in Singapore a publication that is accepted in the Federation?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the application was refused because of the background of the applicant and the scurrilous nature of the previous Saturday Post in the past.

    Mr David Marshall: Has the Minister read the Saturday Post of the present, and would be reconsider his decision?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been reading the Saturday Post since it reappeared, and I would say that there is not only no reason to reverse decision but I think it is most justified that the permit should not be issued.

STUDY GRANTS IN LEGAL EDUCATION TO POLICE OFFICERS


    9. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he will consider making study grants in the field of legal education to police officers showing special aptitude for conducting prosecutions.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, a post of Legal Officer was created in the Police Force in the 1961 Estimates with the duty, among others, of giving advanced training in law to prospective police prosecuting officers. A legal officer was seconded from the State Advocate-General's Chambers to fill this post in May 1961. But as a result of an acute shortage of legal officers, it became necessary recently for the secondment to be terminated temporarily. We hope, however, to fill the post in the near future.

leave and assistance for officers who show special aptitude to study at the Faculty of Law at the University of Singapore?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, we shall consider this suggestion.

DETAINEES STILL UNDER DETENTION


    10. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs how many of the detainees referred to in the Statement submitted by the Singapore Government to the Internal Security Council dated 12th August, 1959, and tabled in this Assembly on 20th July, 1961, are still under detention.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, of the 61 persons under detention at the time when the P.A.P took office, 17 are still under detention.

    Mr David Marshall: I would refer the Minister to the statement of the Deputy Prime Minister and ask whether of the 18 he then referred to as being still under detention and who were to be released forthwith, there are, in fact, still 17. May I expand it, Mr Speaker, since he does not perhaps remember?

    Mr Speaker: Order. There is Standing Order No. 19 (1) (d) which reads:

    `a question shall not refer to debates or answers to questions in the current session;'.

    I do not know whether this refers to a debate or an answer in the current session.

    Mr David Marshall: No, Sir. It was in 1961, a statement by the Deputy Prime Minister that there were 18 detainees left from the Government's two purges, and his words were:

    `Notwithstanding the stand of the British Government in the Internal Security Council, the Singapore Government will issue orders for the release of the detainees in hatches from time to time in accordance with the original proposal of the Singapore Government...'.

    I did refer to it in my question in Hansard, col.1683.

    Mr Speaker: In the previous Session?

    Mr David Marshall: That is so, Sir.

Column: 236



    Mr Speaker: Will the Minister accord the Member a reply?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: I shall inform the Member for Anson in due course.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng (Pasir Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister for Home Affairs tell this House how many of these detainees are ex-officials of the P.A.P. and how many of them have supported the P.A.P. before?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, I am unable to recollect offhand, but I do know at least one who was an expelled member of the P.A.P.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Would the Minister inform the House why there should still be so many detained by the Government?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am surprised that the Member for Queenstown still fails to understand the constitutional set-up of Singapore. He should know by now that there is an Internal Security Council consisting of three parties, and that although it is the Government's intention to release by batches all those detainees detained by the former Government, consent from the other two parties is necessary. We may advise the Yang di-Pertuan Negara to release the detainees, but it is up to the other parties to give their consent as well.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Has any attempt been made to get these people released?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, although I cannot recollect offhand how many have been released. I can assure the Member for Queenstown that not less than three batches have been released since the Deputy Prime Minister made his statement in the last Session of the Assembly.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Does the Minister mean to say that in three batches the Government has released only one detainee? Because the figure given in 1960 was 18, and now the figure given to us is 17. Only one person has been released in three batches.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Unfortunately I do not have the copy of the statement referred to, so I am not in a position to know what this figure 18 referred to. But as far as I could recollect, not less than five have been released. In fact, I would imagine more than five were released since the Deputy Prime Minister made his statement in the last Session.

    Mr David Marshall: I wonder if you will permit me, Sir, to help the Minister with the figures given by the Deputy Prime Minister. If it will please you, Sir, I would like to ask this question. Do we understand that despite the statement of the Deputy Prime Minister that, notwithstanding the stand of the British Government in the Internal Security Council, the Government will issue orders for the release of the detainees in batches, there has, in fact, been no attempt to obtain their release against the wishes of the British Government?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, far from it. In the last few releases, the Government in fact, made the decision first. If the Member for Anson will only read the statements that were released by the Internal Security Council, I think he will get the meaning there.

    Mr Speaker: I will allow one more question. Dr Lee.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: How much longer does the Government intend to keep the other detainees in, and if it is not an inhumanitarian act to keep detainees for longer than five years without trial?

    Mr Speaker: It is a matter of opinion. Mr David Marshall.

TEACHERS TRAINED FOR PRIMARY SCHOOL TEACHING
IN GOVERNMENT SECONDARY SCHOOLS


    11. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Education whether persons trained as teachers for Primary Schools are teaching in `Government Secondary Schools, and what is the number of such persons.

Column: 238



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, to answer the question as put by the Member for Anson whether persons trained as teachers for primary schools are teaching in Government secondary schools, a short answer would be "no". But I think that would not be a fair answer. So may I explain a little for the information of the Member for Anson?

    Persons wishing to take up teaching as a career are expected to have certain basic educational qualifications. After appointment, they are expected to undergo a training course at the Teachers' Training College and thus become trained teachers. Persons so trained at the T.T.C. are not classified as being either trained for primary schools or being trained for secondary schools. They are just trained teachers. As a general rule, however, if College or University graduates are available they will be posted to teach in secondary schools. Out of a total of 1,740 teachers in secondary schools, excluding those in full schools - I may also explain that a "full" school means an elementary and secondary school combined into one, and they do not supply figures as to how many are in the primary section and how many in the secondary section - more than 1,098 are in Government secondary schools as at 30th of September last year. Those are the last available statistics.

    Mr David Marshall: Do I understand the Minister to say then, in fact, that there is no such thing as a primary school teacher trained to teach in primary schools? Is that correct?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I have explained that we do not call them trained primary teachers. They are teachers posted to primary schools or teachers posted to secondary schools.

EXPORT OF MONKEYS FROM BOTANIC GARDENS


    12. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for National Development whether and to what extent arrangements are being made for the export of monkeys from the Botanic Gardens, and the reasons therefor.

Column: 239



    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, there are no arrangements for the export of monkeys from the Botanic Gardens. All the monkeys exported from Singapore are not of Singapore origin and have come in from either the Federation of Malaya or Indonesia.

    Mr David Marshall: Am I to understand from the Minister that, in fact, the monkeys in the Botanic Gardens are not being trapped and removed from the State?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, that is an entirely different question. He asks whether -

    Mr Speaker: It is a different question. Notice is required for that question. Mr David Marshall.

    Mr David Marshall: Sir, what is the difference between exporting -

    Mr Speaker: It is a different question. Notice is required.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: May I explain?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: The Member asked about arrangements made for the export of monkeys. He did not ask whether they were trapped.

    Mr David Marshall: Could the Minister assist us in telling us whether, in fact, (1) there are monkeys from the Botanic Gardens being officially trapped: and (2) whether they are being sent out of the State?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, there are monkeys being trapped in the Botanic Gardens because they are pests and they are not trapped for export purposes.

    Mr David Marshall: Are they being sent out of the State? Would the Minister please tell us?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: No, Sir.

COLLAPSE OF GABLE WALL IN BLOCK
